questions.question: Change the sentence from future continuous to future perfect continuous: They will be training for the marathon all week.
options: a) They will have trained for the marathon all week.
b) They have been training for the marathon all week.
c) They will have been training for the marathon all week.
d) They will train for the marathon all week.
questions.explanation: The future perfect continuous tense is formed with 'will have been' + (verb)ing. 'They will be training' changes to 'They will have been training,' showing the action will continue up to a future point.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: To change 'They were playing' to past perfect, it becomes 'They _____ played.' (had / have)
options: a) had
b) have
questions.explanation: We use 'had' + past participle for past perfect.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from continuous to perfect in the future?
options: a) Will be singing → Will have to sing
b) Will be singing → Will have sing
c) Will be singing → Will have sung
d) Will be singing → Will have singing
questions.explanation: We change 'will be' to 'will have' and use the past participle 'sung'.

questions.question: Change 'She has danced' to present continuous:
options: a) She is dance
b) She is dancing
c) She was dancing
d) She has been dancing
questions.explanation: The structure for the present continuous tense is: 'is/are' + verb+-ing. In this case, 'is' is used because 'she' is a singular subject, and 'dancing' is the verb with the -ing ending.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: To change 'I will have eaten' to future continuous, it becomes 'I will _____ eating.' (be / been)
options: a) be
b) been
questions.explanation: We use 'will be' + verb+ing for future continuous.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from past continuous to past perfect continuous?
options: a) Was running → Had been running
b) Was running → Has been running
c) Was running → Have been running
d) Was running → Had run
questions.explanation: We changed 'was' to 'had been' and kept the '-ing' form.

questions.question: Change the sentence from past perfect to past perfect continuous: She had studied for hours before the exam.
options: a) She had been studying for hours before the exam.
b) She was studying for hours before the exam.
c) She has been studying for hours before the exam.
d) She had studies for hours before the exam.
questions.explanation: The past perfect continuous tense is formed with 'had been' + (verb)ing. 'She had studied' changes to 'She had been studying,' showing the action continued over time before a past event.

questions.question: Change the sentence from present perfect to present perfect continuous: We have worked on this project for months.
options: a) We have been working on this project for months.
b) We are working on this project for months.
c) We had been working on this project for months.
d) We work on this project for months.
questions.explanation: The present perfect continuous tense is formed with 'have/has been' + (verb)ing. 'We have worked' changes to 'We have been working,' showing an ongoing action from the past until now.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from future perfect to future continuous?
options: a) Will have written → Will be written
b) Will have written → Will be wrote
c) Will have written → Will be writing
d) Will have written → Will been writing
questions.explanation: The structure for the future continuous tense is: 'will be' + verb+-ing. Here, 'writing' is the verb in the -ing form, indicating that the action will be in progress.

questions.question: Change the sentence from future perfect to future perfect continuous: He will have completed the assignment by tomorrow.
options: a) He will be completing the assignment by tomorrow.
b) He will have been completing the assignment by tomorrow.
c) He will complete the assignment by tomorrow.
d) He has been completing the assignment by tomorrow.
questions.explanation: The future perfect continuous tense is formed with 'will have been' + (verb)ing. 'He will have completed' changes to 'He will have been completing,' showing the action will be ongoing until a specific future time.

questions.question: Change the sentence from past continuous to past perfect: They were playing soccer when it started to rain.
options: a) They had played soccer when it started to rain.
b) They have played soccer when it started to rain.
c) They had been playing soccer when it started to rain.
d) They played soccer when it started to rain.
questions.explanation: The past perfect continuous tense is formed with 'had been' + (verb)ing. 'They were playing' changes to 'They had been playing,' indicating that the action continued until a certain point.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from past perfect to past continuous?
options: a) Had sung → Was/Were singing
b) Had sung → Is singing
c) Had sung → Have singing
d) Had sung → Has been singing
questions.explanation: We change 'had' to 'was/were' and add '-ing' to the verb. The structure for the past continuous tense is: 'was/were' + verb+-ing.

questions.question: Change the sentence from present continuous to present perfect: I am cleaning my room now.
options: a) I have cleaned my room.
b) I had cleaned my room.
c) I have been cleaning my room.
d) I was cleaning my room.
questions.explanation: The present perfect tense is formed with 'have/has' + past participle. 'I am cleaning' changes to 'I have cleaned,' indicating a completed action with present relevance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: To change 'I have eaten' to present continuous, it becomes 'I _____ eating.' (are / am)
options: a) are
b) am
questions.explanation: We use 'am' + verb+ing for present continuous.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from present continuous to present perfect continuous?
options: a) Is walking → Has walking
b) Is walking → Had been walking
c) Is walking → Have/Has been walking
d) Is walking → Was walking
questions.explanation: The structure for the present perfect continuous tense is: 'has/have been' + verb+-ing.

questions.question: Change "We had been playing" to past continuous:
options: a) We have been playing
b) We are playing
c) We were playing
d) We will be playing
questions.explanation: The structure for the past continuous tense is: "was/were" + verb+-ing. "Were" is used with the plural subject "we."

questions.question: Fill in the blank: To change "They will sing" to future continuous, it becomes "They will _____ singing." (have / be)
options: a) have
b) be
questions.explanation: The structure for the future continuous tense is: "will be" + verb+-ing.

questions.question: Change the sentence from future continuous to future perfect: We will be travelling to Spain next week.
options: a) By next week, we will have travelled to Spain.
b) We will be travelling to Spain next week.
c) We have been travelling to Spain next week.
d) We will have been travelling to Spain next week.
questions.explanation: The future perfect tense is formed with "will have" + past participle. "We will be travelling" changes to "We will have travelled," showing that the action will be completed by a specific future time.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from past continuous to past perfect?
options: a) Were dancing → Has danced
b) Were dancing → Have danced
c) Were dancing → Had danced
d) Were dancing → Had been danced
questions.explanation: We change "were" to "had" and use the past participle "danced". The structure for the past perfect tense is: "had" + past participle of the verb. In this case, the past participle of "dance" is "danced."

questions.question: Change "He has been singing" to present continuous:
options: a) He was singing
b) He is singing
c) He will be singing
d) He had been singing
questions.explanation: We change "has been" to "is" and keep the "-ing" form. The structure for the present continuous tense is: "is/are" + verb+-ing. For the subject "he," you would use "is."

questions.question: Change the sentence from past perfect to past continuous: He had repaired the car before leaving.
options: a) He was repairing the car before leaving.
b) He has repaired the car before leaving.
c) He repairs the car before leaving.
d) He had been repairing the car before leaving.
questions.explanation: The past continuous tense is formed with "was/were" + (verb)ing. "He had repaired" changes to "He was repairing," indicating that the action was ongoing at a certain past time.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from future perfect continuous to future continuous?
options: a) Will have been running → Will be running
b) Will have been running → Will run
c) Will have been running → Will have run
d) Will have been running → Was running
questions.explanation: We change "will have been" to "will be" and keep the "-ing" form.

questions.question: Change the sentence from present perfect to present continuous: They have completed their tasks for today.
options: a) They are completing their tasks for today.
b) They were completing their tasks for today.
c) They have been completing their tasks for today.
d) They had completed their tasks for today.
questions.explanation: The present continuous tense is formed with "is/am/are" + (verb)ing. "They have completed" changes to "They are completing," indicating an action happening now.

questions.question: Which is the correct change from present perfect to present perfect continuous?
options: a) Have written → Had been writing
b) Have written → Has be writing
c) Have written → Have been writing
d) Have written → Will have been writing
questions.explanation: We change "have" to "have been" and add "-ing" to the verb. The structure for the present perfect continuous tense is: "have/has been" + verb+-ing.

questions.question: Change the sentence from future perfect to future continuous: She will have baked the cake by tonight.
options: a) She will be baking the cake by tonight.
b) She has been baking the cake by tonight.
c) She was baking the cake by tonight.
d) She had baked the cake by tonight.
questions.explanation: The future continuous tense is formed with "will be" + (verb)ing. "She will have baked" changes to "She will be baking," indicating an action that will be ongoing at a future point.
